hook.text: Your shoulder can rotate in a full circle. Your knee can't. Joint design dictates what movement is possible.

buildup.text: Ball-and-socket joints â€” shoulder and hip â€” allow the widest range: flexion, extension, rotation, and more.

discovery.text: The hip socket is deep, giving stability. The shoulder socket is shallow, giving range but less stability.

twist.text: That's why shoulders dislocate far more than hips. The trade-off between range and stability is real.

climax.text: Understanding your joint type tells you what to train. Shoulders need stability; hips need mobility.

punchline.text: Joint shape determines movement. You can't stretch past anatomy.

quiz.question: Why do shoulders dislocate more often than hips?
options: The shoulder socket is shallower, trading stability for range
Shoulder muscles are weaker than hip muscles
